conclusion: To determine if the displacements of cars A and B are the same, analyze their velocity-time graphs.
The displacement of an object is given by the area under its velocity-time graph.
Car A's velocity-time graph is the curve labeled A. Car B's velocity-time graph is the curve labeled B.
The displacement of each car is the area under its respective velocity-time graph from t=0 to t=t1.
For Car A, the area under the curve from t=0 to t=t1 is the region bounded by the curve A, the time axis, and the vertical lines at t=0 and t=t1.
For Car B, the area under the curve from t=0 to t=t1 is the region bounded by the curve B, the time axis, and the vertical lines at t=0 and t=t1.
By visually inspecting the graph, the area under curve A is larger than the area under curve B within the given time interval.
Since the area under curve A is larger than the area under curve B, the displacement of Car A is greater than the displacement of Car B during the time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
No, the displacements of cars A and B are not the same during the time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
